Hide your head in the sand little girl

These lyrics detail the consequences for breaking Lennon’s fidelity rules: death.

The phrase “head in the sand” describes someone that chooses to dodge a particular situation by refusing to acknowledge it’s existence. It alludes to the ostrich tactic of hiding their heads in the sand when danger arrives; this is not actually the case.



Both men and women who cannot cope with breakups fit this description as well; they deny that there ever was a relationship to speed up the process of moving on. Lennon could mean that this girl is better off forgetting him than anything else.



If Lennon is referring to murder, there are several notable cases where victims were found on the beach. One such case is the Australian mystery of the Somerton Man, where an unidentified man was found dead. His cause of death, identity, and killer still remain unknown. It is possible Lennon heard about this case and thought about it as he wrote this song; anyone who betrays John Lennon might have an unexplainable death.

You better run for your life if you can, little girl

The lyrics recall Lennon’s previous excursions into misogyny, “I’ll Cry Instead” and “You Can’t Do That”, both from A Hard Day’s Night.

John was always on the run, running for his life. He was married; whereas none of my songs would have ‘catch you with another man’. It was never a concern of mine, at all, because I had a girlfriend and I would go with other girls; it was a perfectly open relationship so I wasn’t as worried about that as John was. A bit of a macho song.
- Paul McCartney

Let this be a sermon
 I mean everything I’ve said

The song, cryptic to begin with, provides this particularly disturbing lyric. Lennon is letting her know, she better take his word as gospel. If his girl thinks he is speaking hypothetically, she is mistaken. Quite the song from the same band who brought you, “All You Need is Love”.

I’d rather see you dead, little girl
 Than to be with another man
 You better keep your head, little girl
 Or you won’t know where I am

Lennon later expressed his dislike of the song, saying he “always hated” “Run For Your Life”. In 1973 he described it as his “least favourite Beatles song”, although he did claim that it was one of George Harrison’s favourites.

Just a sort of throwaway song of mine that I never thought much of, but it was always a favourite of George’s.
It has a line from an old Presley song: “I’d rather see you dead, little girl, than to be with another man” is a line from an old blues song that Presley did once.
-John Lennon

The upbeat, easygoing groove of this song is completely at odds with its casually paranoid tone of impending retribution. The last line is chilling: “Or you won’t know where I am”. The suggestion, plain as daylight, is that he’ll be behind “little girl” with a weapon in his hand, and she won’t know what hit her. Hence the warning of the title: “Run For Your Life”. No wonder Lennon later disowned the song!

Well I’d rather see you dead, little girl
 Than to be with another man
These lines are ripped word-for-word from Elvis Presley’s Baby Let’s Play House. Lennon would later go on to disown this song and some others he wrote for its misogynistic language.
